y, for the same reasons I was drawn to Audacity. I have tried Goldwave a fe=
w times. But couldn't remember the features. The High or Low pass filters a=
re very helpfull. As well as the pitch (this changes the voice either highe=
r or lower) that helps bring it out of the "muddy" static level. As far as =
using the "noise eliminator" be careful here...a little goes a long way. It=
 will make you audio sound like a bad organ piano :) The high or low filter=
 actually does what we are wanting the noise filter to do anyway. And doesn=
't add its own melodies. --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com, "April Abercrombie=
" <april@...> wrote:

using Goldwave for years, and it is very good for low-priced software. I tr=
ied Audacity, but didn't like interface as much, by that is just my prefere=
nce.

  > Hi, give the AUDACITY software another try. Has option to slow the r=
ecording down. Another nice feature is that you can use either a highpass o=
r lowpass filter (sometimes that is all that is needed) and changing the PI=
TCH is a very handy tool. Always KEEP an original copy of your recordings. =
I just save a copy from inside audacity (to desktop or somewhere) then I wi=
ll start my work on trying to clear it up. Save the original (and proceedin=
g enhanced version(s) by using the "file" button at to left corner oif prog=
ram. There you would SAVE "selection" as MP3.(To upload to here) or save to=
 WAV (is bigger) but higher qulity. Can always convert the wav to mp3 from =
withing audacity also. *you will need to get the mps "pluging" from the web=
site, and follow the information to install it "manually" (once is only nee=
ded) that way you get the mp3 converter program free. But really...Audacity=
 is a pretty good program to have round. Has a nice "undo" fesature too, if=
 you make a mistake. Happy Hunting ;) Jim H --- In EVP-ITC@yahoogroups.com,=
